list_definition.definition: a quick touch or light knock or blow

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I heard a tap at the door.

list_definition.definition: (often with at, on or with) to give a light knock (on or with something)
any of several types of device (usually with a handle and valve that can be shut or opened) for controlling the flow of liquid or gas from a pipe, barrel etc ; faucet( American)
to start using (a source, supply etc)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The country has many natural resources that have not yet been tapped.

list_definition.definition: to attach a device to (someone’s telephone wires) in order to be able to listen to his telephone conversations

list_ex_of_english: Within the groups of metered tap and non-tap households, however, our data are likely to be largely representative.
A number of studies have suggested that lexical decision and naming tap different aspects of post-lexical processing.
Alternatively it could be that this factor taps into some other, structural, dimension of the local area.
Thus, vocabulary knowledge and the skills tapped by the ability to recognize written words were associated with naming ability.
The hind legs rubbed or tapped repeatedly on the ventral surface of the female's abdomen.
Whenever a town succeeded in tapping a larger supply of water, its drainage became a more acute problem.
We, like many users of the task, would not want to claim that it taps directly into necessary stages of speech processing.
This test taps children's ability to recall appropriate words in context and provides information pertaining to receptive and expressive vocabulary.
